body:
This happened for me too. It doesn't look like anyone has been downvoting me, I don't think I even have as much posts as I lost rep.

I asked on Discord and nobody really knows why, but it seems to happen to a lot of people. I thought it may be some kind of algorithm change, but there have been no statements from the admins on this.

body:
Thanks for the explanation, as far as it goes. Being a non-techie, I can only talk by analogy. This sounds a bit like someone telling me, helpfully, just how the dealer fucked up the repair of my truck. Sure, I'm always interested in the information, just as I'm interested in yours. Still, though, in the end I really just want the truck to work and the site to work.

I'm glad that people like yourself know the details, just as I'm happy that there are car mechanics, plumbers, electricians, and so on. But I'm a user and not a mechanic or website designer, and I expect my truck, my toilet, my lights, and the websites I visit to work. We are now nearly 40 years into the era of computers connected to the telecom network. In automotive terms, that would be the late 1950s or early 1960s. This stuff should work a lot better than it does.

Ruqqus is hardly the only site or software plagued by usability issues, but I think it's high time that the techno-nerds did a better job. By the way, I also think that no one should work for free. One way or another they will and should be paid. I've been planning to donate to Ruqqus, but I'm going to wait on that until I have more confidence in this platform. I appreciate their work, which I'm sure is full of frustrations whose details I cannot ever really understand, but they need to get their act together.
body_html:
Thanks for the explanation, as far as it goes. Being a non-techie, I can only talk by analogy. This sounds a bit like someone telling me, helpfully, just how the dealer fucked up the repair of my truck. Sure, I'm always interested in the information, just as I'm interested in yours. Still, though, in the end I really just want the truck to work and the site to work.

I'm glad that people like yourself know the details, just as I'm happy that there are car mechanics, plumbers, electricians, and so on. But I'm a user and not a mechanic or website designer, and I expect my truck, my toilet, my lights, and the websites I visit to work. We are now nearly 40 years into the era of computers connected to the telecom network. In automotive terms, that would be the late 1950s or early 1960s. This stuff should work a lot better than it does.

Ruqqus is hardly the only site or software plagued by usability issues, but I think it's high time that the techno-nerds did a better job. By the way, I also think that no one should work for free. One way or another they will and should be paid. I've been planning to donate to Ruqqus, but I'm going to wait on that until I have more confidence in this platform. I appreciate their work, which I'm sure is full of frustrations whose details I cannot ever really understand, but they need to get their act together.

post.title: I seem to have lost 100 of my rep in the last 24 hours.

body:
You can lose it with shadow fuzzing. If you are making multiple accounts and spam up-voting your primary account Ruqqus algorithms will start taking your upvotes away. 

You can also lose it with down-vote brigading by upset users who look through your post history down-voting everything. Shadow-fuzzing doesn't seem to effect down-votes. It's a good idea to hide your post history to avoid this.
body_html:
You can lose it with shadow fuzzing. If you are making multiple accounts and spam up-voting your primary account Ruqqus algorithms will start taking your upvotes away.

You can also lose it with down-vote brigading by upset users who look through your post history down-voting everything. Shadow-fuzzing doesn't seem to effect down-votes. It's a good idea to hide your post history to avoid this.
